libraryinfo.librarypurpose: A library implementation of C++/CLI-style properties with full C++ integration.

section.title: Background
section.para: The concept of a property originated in GUI and Rapid Application Development (RAD) environments, providing introspection/reflection and RAD-based value manipulation. A property is an entity that behaves like a public data member, but the value is retrieved through a getter function and assigned using a setter function.

section.title: Why Are Properties Useful?
section.para: One of the principles of OOP is that of encapsulation. This is where you prevent direct manipulation of an objects internal state, but provide methods and constructors to control it. A motivation for this is to validate the data (for example, ensuring that the month value is in range), however this leads to potentially non-intuitive usage, for example:
The use of properties here can simplify such usage by providing a more intuitive C++-style syntax:

Another use is in writing more generic code. For example, GUI libraries provide a data structure for providing a rectangle in 2D cartesian coordinates. If you want to provide access to the rectangle data without restricting yourself to a particular platform, properties become essential. They allow you to define xpos, ypos, width and height properties and map them to the corresponding implementation.

If you are a COM programmer, the C++ classes that define a COM interface have many get/set functions for various data elements. Using properties allows you to write code with these interfaces in a more intuitive way.

section.title: Properties In C++
section.para: So far we have seen property mechanisms that require intervention by the compiler to add the boilerplate code needed for properties to interact with C++. As such, properties are compiler-dependant and are not available to a purely C++98 conforming compiler. Therefore, code using properties is not portable.

As well as not being standard code, properties do not always interact with normal C++ code as you would expect. For example, if you have a property that is declared as an array of a type that has a subscript operator (like std::map), the compiler will complain if you attempt to access the subscript operator together with indexing the property. Lois Goldthwaite has published a proposal for C++ properties implemented as a library solution (N1615). I have used that for the inspiration for this library.

section.title: Properties Overview
section.para: In describing properties, I have borrowed terminology from Tensor algebra. As such, the number of indices associated with a property is given by the Rank of that property. For example, a matrix property would be of rank 2 since it has two indices.

The implementation of properties is split into two groups. There are the classes that provide the boilerplate code required to provide the natural usage of a property from within C++. This group is defined independantly of how a property is stored and manipulated.
The second group provide get and set functions to allow access to the property. They have the following typedefs:

entry.simpara: The base type of the property.

This is the type of the value that is passed to the property implementation in order to initialize that property. For example, passing a reference to a variable if the property is an aliasing property.
If value_type provides subscripting facilities, this type specifies the value returned by the subscript operator.
If value_type provides subscripting facilities, this specifies the type of the index used by the subscript operator.

section.para: In order to simplify the creation of these typedefs, the property library provides two classes:
section.programlisting:
template < typename ValueType, typename ConstructorType = ValueType, typename SubscriptType = ValueType &, typename Index = int > struct boost::property_type;
template< typename Prop, typename ConstructorType = Prop > struct boost::inherited_property_type;
section.para: boost::property_type will define a new property type and boost::inherited_property_type will take the types as defined in Prop and bring them into scope of this property, except for constructor_type that is defined independantly.

section.title: Object Properties
section.para: An object property is a property that is a wrapper around getter and setter functions in a class. This is implemented via the boost::readonly_object_property class for properties that only supply a get method and boost::object_property for properties that have both get and set methods.

section.title: Assignment
section.para: Because properties prevent access to copy constructor and assignment operations, the following example produces an error:
section.programlisting: object o1, o2; o1.Val = 2; // ok o2.Val = o1.Val; // error o2.Val = o1.Val(); // ok o2.Val = o1.Val.get(); // ok

section.title: Using Inside A Class
section.para: If you are using properties in a class (like object in the examples) then you need to suppress the compiler-generated copy constructors and assignment operations. You can either make them private in your class or provide your own implementations of them.
Note that this is only needed for classes that have properties as members. Other classes derived from them do not need to do this unless they contain properties themselves.
